ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An overview of ancient Chinese archaeology and history
Great introduction to course to the archaeology of China, covering both history and theory.
Honestly just a lot of really interesting facts and history about a place I wasnt familiar with

This course taught me everything from ancient Chinese history, excavation techniques to bio-archeology! I loved the comprehensive way this course explained both methods and history. At the end of this class, I felt that learning about archeological methods put me in a strong position to analyse journal articles. Furthermore, digging into the ways that contemporary artefacts are acquired is often overlooked and I felt that Professor Wolin covered the ethics of archeology very successfully.
We learned about the basic procedures and theories behind archaeological sciences, which was very helpful for people outside of the major.

I studied about several archeological approaches for studying ancient Chinese history. Not only did I learn about Chinese history, but it also clarified what anthropological and archeology studies are like at Yale.
We learned all of the ins and outs of ancient Chinese history and all about the archaeological methods and analyses used to interpret and understand this unique history.

-history and archaeology of China
-basics of archaeology 
-creating a "museum exhibit" 
-writing a research paper

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The course was organized chronologically and was very efficient for learning. Course modules were organized so that we were able to always know what readings and things were required for each class. Assignment details were clearly laid out and communicated with rubrics. Weekly reading responses allowed for some flexibility as well while also keeping you accountable for reading during most of the semester. 
Weaknesses: None that I can particularly think of.
Overall course was designed well to facilitate and engage student learning.

I thought the course spent too much time on the slow progression of food production in 30 different regional Neolithic cultures a lay person would never have heard of before. I wish instead wed been given a higher level overview. Without that big picture I felt lost and bored in class, because we were just learning details that I couldnt keep straight and struggled to place into a broader narrative.  The second half of the course seemed more interesting, but I had already burned up the energy I set aside for this class. I think a topical organization would have taught me more than the chronological one actually used in class.
Projects were a strength. Made me learn the material in fun way

This course was a great introduction to both archaeology as well as ancient Chinese history. However, it was difficult to keep the chronology and geography of China in order due to my lack of familiarity with it all. If there were a map or timeline with the chronological history of China, it would have been easier to keep everything in order.

strengths:
- organization
- assignments 
- projects/papers

weaknesses:
- not super engaging lectures 
- lack of diversity in types of homework (mostly readings)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Great way to engage with Chinese archaeology in a stress-free class.
Yes, very interesting class for majors and non-majors, especially those who have an interest in Chinese history or art history.
Not unless they had previous familiarity with the topic and knew for certain they wanted to study it again
Yes
Yes! The breadth of material this course covers made it really engaging!
The class isn't terrible in terms of workload, and you can definitely get something out of it if you do the readings and/or listen in class.

Yes, this was a really good overview of Chinese archaeology, which is exactly what was promised. Professor Wolin is also very passionate about the topic and often engages with the biases that affect archaeological study as well as the power dynamics that are inherent with studying history that is rooted in modern day geopolitics.

Yes! Professor Wolin does well at teaching this subject because she fosters a welcoming environment for questions and conversations. This course is ideal for anyone interested in archeological and anthropological studies regardless of their degree.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone interested in archaeology or Chinese history.

I would only recommend this course to a student interested in history or archaeology because it is not very engaging otherwise. The lectures were very similar every day, which led to a lack of engagement. I would say for a student just looking for a new course to take, I wouldn't recommend it.
